newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico proposal would require casinos to go public.
newsitem.headline: Mexico proposal would require casinos to go public.

text.p: A proposed law to allow casino gambling in Mexico would require gaming halls to issue publicly traded stock equal to at least 20 percent of their capital, according to a draft of the legislation.
The Casino Regulating Council would require gaming companies "to issue not less than 20 percent of their capital for public investment," the proposed legislation says.
The document, written by officials from the finance, tourism and interior ministries, would allow foreign companies to operate casinos, but they would need permission from a special commission.
The draft of the law, however, restricts the location of casinos to tourist centers. Permits to operate casinos would be issued for 25 years at a time.
"Casinos can only operate when they form part of the Integrated tourist centers that the council determines, based on the Federal Tourism Law," the document says.
Existing tourist centers that want to add casinos must control at least a 25 percent interest in the gambling halls, according to the draft.
The proposed law includes a number of measures to guard against money laundering. It would require casinos to identify gamblers who buy extraordinary amounts of gambling chips.
Opposition legislator Rene Arce of the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party (PRD) opposes the law, saying Mexico is not prepared to regulate the gambling industry.
"First we have to reform some (government) institutions so that the casinos don't become a security problem, including a national security problem," Arce told Reuters in an interview.
Casino gambling was outlawed in 1938 by President Lazaro Cardenas.
